\\/D:\\/repos\\/rr\\/source\\/manual\\/p: This tutorial demonstrates how to create custom shaders and materials for a particle system, providing functionality not available in the core engine.
Este tutorial demonstra como criar shaders personalizados e materiais para um sistema de partículas, fornecendo funcionalidade não disponível no motor central.
This tutorial demonstrates how to create custom shaders and materials for a particle system, providing functionality not available in the core engine.
It focuses on shaders and rendering.
Ele se concentra em shaders e renderização.
It focuses on shaders and rendering.
For simulation, see the <g1>custom particles tutorial<\/g1>.
Para a simulação, veja o tutorial <g1>custom partículas<\/g1>.
For simulation, see the <g1>custom particles tutorial<\/g1>.
If you're not familiar with editing particles, see <g1>Create particles<\/g1>.
Se você não estiver familiarizado com as partículas de edição, veja as partículas <g1>Create<\/g1>.
If you're not familiar with editing particles, see <g1>Create particles<\/g1>.
This project contains four scenes, each demonstrating a different way to use particles:
Este projeto contém quatro cenas, cada uma demonstrando uma maneira diferente de usar partículas:
This project contains four scenes, each demonstrating a different way to use particles:
<g1>Partículas Animadas<\/g1>, <g2>Partículas de Crianças<\/g2>, <g3>Materiais personalizados<\/g3>, e <g4>Partículas personalizadas<\/g4>.
There are three particle entities in the scene:
Há três entidades de partículas no local:
There are three particle entities in the scene:
<g1>Rad Particle System<\/g1>, <g2>Radial Particle System<\/g2>, and <g3>Two Textures Particle System<\/g3>.
<g1>Rad Particle System<\/g1>, <g2>Radial Particle System<\/g2> e <g3>Dois Textures Particle System<\/g3>.
<g1>Rad Particle System<\/g1>, <g2>Radial Particle System<\/g2>, and <g3>Two Textures Particle System<\/g3>.
Select one of the particle entities and navigate to its source particle system, expanding the emitter in it and its material.
Selecione uma das entidades de partículas e navegue até seu sistema de partículas de origem, expandindo a emissora nela e seu material.
Select one of the particle entities and navigate to its source particle system, expanding the emitter in it and its material.
The <g1>red particle system<\/g1> has a very simple customization.
O sistema de partículas <g1>red<\/g1> tem uma personalização muito simples.
The <g1>red particle system<\/g1> has a very simple customization.
Since the <g2>material maps<\/g2> already provide an option to use shaders as a leaf node input, we can create a custom shader and assign it to that node.
Como os mapas materiais <g2><\/g2> já fornecem uma opção para usar shaders como uma entrada de nó de folha, podemos criar um shader personalizado e atribuí-lo a esse nó.
Since the <g2>material maps<\/g2> already provide an option to use shaders as a leaf node input, we can create a custom shader and assign it to that node.
First, create a shader (<g1>ComputeColorRed.sdsl<\/g1>) with a derived class for <g2>ComputeColor<\/g2>:
Primeiro, crie um shader (<g1>ComputeColorRed.sdsl<\/g1>) com uma classe derivada para <g2>ComputeColor<\/g2>:
First, create a shader (<g1>ComputeColorRed.sdsl<\/g1>) with a derived class for <g2>ComputeColor<\/g2>:
The only thing this shader does is return the red color for pixel shading every time <g1>Compute<\/g1> is called.
A única coisa que este shader faz é retornar a cor vermelha para pixel shading cada vez <g1>Compute<\/g1> é chamado.
The only thing this shader does is return the red color for pixel shading every time <g1>Compute<\/g1> is called.
We'll try something more difficult later, but for now let's keep it simple.
Vamos tentar algo mais difícil mais tarde, mas por agora vamos mantê-lo simples.
We'll try something more difficult later, but for now let's keep it simple.
Save the file and reload the scripts in Game Studio.
Salve o arquivo e recarregue os scripts no Game Studio.
Save the file and reload the scripts in Game Studio.
You should see the new shader in <g1>Asset View<\/g1>.
Você deve ver o novo shader em <g1>Asset View<\/g1>.
You should see the new shader in <g1>Asset View<\/g1>.
If the shader isn't there, reload the project.
Se o shader não estiver lá, recarregue o projeto.
If the shader isn't there, reload the project.
Once the shader is loaded, you can access it in the <g1>Property Grid<\/g1> under the <g2>dynamic emissive material<\/g2> for the particles.
Uma vez que o shader é carregado, você pode acessá-lo no <g1>Property Grid<\/g1> sob o material emissivo dinâmico <g2> para as partículas.
Once the shader is loaded, you can access it in the <g1>Property Grid<\/g1> under the <g2>dynamic emissive material<\/g2> for the particles.
Choose a type of shader and, from the drop-down menu, select the shader you just added to the scene.
Escolha um tipo de shader e, no menu suspenso, selecione o shader que você acabou de adicionar à cena.
Choose a type of shader and, from the drop-down menu, select the shader you just added to the scene.
With Game Studio running, edit and save <g1>ComputeColorRed.sdsl<\/g1> to make them yellow.
Com Game Studio executando, edite e salve <g1>ComputeColorRed.sdsl<\/g1> para torná-los amarelos.
With Game Studio running, edit and save <g1>ComputeColorRed.sdsl<\/g1> to make them yellow.
Because Stride supports dynamic shader compilation, the particles immediately turn yellow.
Porque Stride suporta compilação de shader dinâmico, as partículas imediatamente ficam amarelas.
Because Stride supports dynamic shader compilation, the particles immediately turn yellow.
For the next shader we'll use texture coordinates expose arbitrary values to the editor.
Para o próximo shader vamos usar coordenadas de textura expor valores arbitrários ao editor.
For the next shader we'll use texture coordinates expose arbitrary values to the editor.
radial flutuante Distância = comprimento (streams. TexCoord - float2(0.5, 0.5)) * 2;
\/\/ We want to allow the intensity to grow a lot, but cap the alpha to 1
\/\/ Queremos permitir que a intensidade cresça muito, mas cap o alfa para 1
\/\/ We want to allow the intensity to grow a lot, but cap the alpha to 1
\/\/ Remember that we use a premultiplied alpha pipeline so all color values should be premultiplied
\/\/ Lembre-se de que usamos um pipeline alfa pré-multiplicado para que todos os valores de cor devem ser pré-multiplicados
\/\/ Remember that we use a premultiplied alpha pipeline so all color values should be premultiplied
This is similar to <g1>ComputeColorRed<\/g1> and can be compiled and loaded the same way.
Isso é semelhante a <g1>ComputeColorRed<\/g1> e pode ser compilado e carregado da mesma maneira.
This is similar to <g1>ComputeColorRed<\/g1> and can be compiled and loaded the same way.
The shader now inherits from the <g1>Texturing<\/g1> shader base class as well.
O shader agora herda do <g1>Texturing<\/g1> classe base shader também.
The shader now inherits from the <g1>Texturing<\/g1> shader base class as well.
This allows it to use texture coordinates in from the streams.
Isso permite que ele use coordenadas de textura nas correntes.
This allows it to use texture coordinates in from the streams.
On the material side in Game Studio, we can force the texture coordinates to be streamed in case we don't use texture animation.
No lado material do Game Studio, podemos forçar as coordenadas de textura a serem transmitidas caso não usemos animação de textura.
On the material side in Game Studio, we can force the texture coordinates to be streamed in case we don't use texture animation.
The input values <g1>float4 ColorCenter<\/g1> and <g2>float4 ColorEdge<\/g2> in our shader are permutations.
Os valores de entrada <g1>float4 ColorCenter<\/g1> e <g2>float4 ColorEdge<\/g2> em nosso shader são permutações.
The input values <g1>float4 ColorCenter<\/g1> and <g2>float4 ColorEdge<\/g2> in our shader are permutations.
When we load the shader the Property Grid displays them under the <g3>Generics<\/g3> dictionary.
Quando carregamos o shader, o Property Grid os exibe sob o dicionário <g3>Generics<\/g3>.
When we load the shader the Property Grid displays them under the <g3>Generics<\/g3> dictionary.
The values we set here will be used by the <g1>ComputeColorRadial<\/g1> shader for the particles.
Os valores que estabelecemos aqui serão usados pelo shader <g1>ComputeColorRadial<\/g1> para as partículas.
The values we set here will be used by the <g1>ComputeColorRadial<\/g1> shader for the particles.
The rest of the shader simply calculates a gradient color based on the distance of the shaded pixel from the center of the billboard.
O resto do shader simplesmente calcula uma cor gradiente com base na distância do pixel sombreado do centro do outdoor.
The rest of the shader simply calculates a gradient color based on the distance of the shaded pixel from the center of the billboard.

This demonstrates how to create custom materials and effects for the particles.
Isso demonstra como criar materiais e efeitos personalizados para as partículas.
This demonstrates how to create custom materials and effects for the particles.
The <g1>DynamicColor<\/g1> material supports one RGBA channel.
O material <g1>DynamicColor<\/g1> suporta um canal RGBA.
The <g1>DynamicColor<\/g1> material supports one RGBA channel.
For our sample, we'll separate the RGB and A channels, allowing them to use different texture coordinate animations and different textures and binary trees to compute the color.
Para a nossa amostra, separaremos os canais RGB e A, permitindo-lhes usar diferentes animações de coordenadas de textura e diferentes texturas e árvores binárias para calcular a cor.
For our sample, we'll separate the RGB and A channels, allowing them to use different texture coordinate animations and different textures and binary trees to compute the color.
Parameter keys are used to map data and pass it to the shader.
As chaves do parâmetro são usadas para mapear dados e passá-lo para o shader.
Parameter keys are used to map data and pass it to the shader.
Some of them are generated, and we can define our own too.
Alguns deles são gerados, e podemos definir o nosso próprio também.
Some of them are generated, and we can define our own too.
If we define more streams in our shader (<g1>ParticleCustomShader<\/g1>), they're exported to an automatically generated class.
Se definirmos mais fluxos em nosso shader (<g1>ParticleCustomShader<\/g1>), eles são exportados para uma classe gerada automaticamente.
If we define more streams in our shader (<g1>ParticleCustomShader<\/g1>), they're exported to an automatically generated class.

As we saw above, the generated class has the same name and the namespace is <g1>Stride.Rendering<\/g1>, so we have to make our class partial and match the namespace.

It defines two composed shaders, <g1>baseColor<\/g1> and <g2>abseIntensity<\/g2>, where we'll plug our generated shaders for RGB and A respectively.
Ele define dois shaders compostos, <g1>baseColor<\/g1> e <g2>abseIntensity<\/g2>, onde vamos conectar nossos shaders gerados para RGB e A respectivamente.
It defines two composed shaders, <g1>baseColor<\/g1> and <g2>abseIntensity<\/g2>, where we'll plug our generated shaders for RGB and A respectively.
It inherits <g3>ParticleBase<\/g3> which already defines <g4>VSMain<\/g4>, <g5>PSMain<\/g5> and texturing, and uses very simple <g6>Shading()<\/g6> method.
Ele herda <g3>ParticleBase<\/g3> que já define <g4>VSMain<\/g4>, <g5>PSMain<\/g5> e texturing, e usa método muito simples <g6>Shading()<\/g6>.
It inherits <g3>ParticleBase<\/g3> which already defines <g4>VSMain<\/g4>, <g5>PSMain<\/g5> and texturing, and uses very simple <g6>Shading()<\/g6> method.
By overriding the <g1>Shading()<\/g1> method we can define our custom behavior.
Ao substituir o método <g1>Shading()<\/g1> podemos definir nosso comportamento personalizado.
By overriding the <g1>Shading()<\/g1> method we can define our custom behavior.

Because the composed shaders we use are derived from <g2>ComputeColor<\/g2>, we can easily evaluate them using <g3>Compute()<\/g3>, which gives us the root of the compute tree for color and intensity.

Como os shaders compostos que usamos são derivados de <g2>ComputeColor<\/g2>, podemos facilmente avaliá-los usando <g3>Compute()<\/g3>, o que nos dá a raiz da árvore de computação para cor e intensidade.

Because the composed shaders we use are derived from <g2>ComputeColor<\/g2>, we can easily evaluate them using <g3>Compute()<\/g3>, which gives us the root of the compute tree for color and intensity.
Our effect describes how to mix and compose the shaders.
Nosso efeito descreve como misturar e compor os shaders.
Our effect describes how to mix and compose the shaders.

<g1>ParticleBaseKeys<\/g1> and <g2>ParticleBaseEffect<\/g2> are required by the base shader which we inherit.

The <g1>baseColor<\/g1> and <g2>baseIntensity<\/g2> parameters are from the shader we created earlier.
Last, we need a material which sets all the keys and uses the newly created effect.
Por último, precisamos de um material que define todas as chaves e usa o efeito recém-criado.
Last, we need a material which sets all the keys and uses the newly created effect.

Vamos copiar @'Stride.Particles.Materials.ParticleMaterialComputeColor' em <g1>ParticleCustomMaterial.cs<\/g1> em nosso projeto e personalizá-lo para usar dois shaders para árvores binárias de cor.
We'll copy @'Stride.Particles.Materials.ParticleMaterialComputeColor' into <g1>ParticleCustomMaterial.cs<\/g1> in our project and customize it to use two shaders for color binary trees.

In addition to the already existing @'Stride.Rendering.Materials.IComputeColor', we'll use @'Stride.Rendering.Materials.IComputeScalar' for intensity, which returns a float, rather than a float4.

In addition to the already existing @'Stride.Rendering.Materials.IComputeColor', we'll use @'Stride.Rendering.Materials.IComputeScalar' for intensity, which returns a float, rather than a float4.

We will also add another  @'Stride.Particles.Materials.UVBuilder' for a second texture coordinates animation.

var shaderBaseColor = ComputeColor.GenerateShaderSource (shaderGeneratorContext, novo MaterialColorKeysCompute (ParticleCustomShaderKeys.EmissiveMap, ParticleCustomShaderKeys.EmissiveValue, Color.White));

var shader BaseScalar = ComputeScalar.GenerateShaderSource(shaderGeneratorContext, new MaterialComputeColorKeys (ParticleCustomShaderKeys.IntensityMap, ParticleCustomShaderKeys.IntensityValue, Color.White));
We load the two shaders: one for the main color and one for the intensity.
Nós carregamos os dois shaders: um para a cor principal e um para a intensidade.
We load the two shaders: one for the main color and one for the intensity.

These are similar to the shaders we wrote manually in the last two examples, except we generate them on the fly directly from the <g1>ComputeColor<\/g1> and <g2>ComputeScalar<\/g2> properties, which you can edit in the Property Grid.

Estes são semelhantes aos shaders que escrevemos manualmente nos dois últimos exemplos, exceto que os geramos na mosca diretamente das propriedades <g1>ComputeColor<\/g1> e <g2>ComputeScalar<\/g2>, que você pode editar na Grade de Propriedade.

These are similar to the shaders we wrote manually in the last two examples, except we generate them on the fly directly from the <g1>ComputeColor<\/g1> and <g2>ComputeScalar<\/g2> properties, which you can edit in the Property Grid.
The generated code is similar to the shader code we wrote in the way that it calls <g3>Compute()<\/g3> and it returns the final result of our color or scalar compute tree.
O código gerado é semelhante ao código do shader que escrevemos da maneira que ele chama <g3>Compute()<\/g3> e retorna o resultado final de nossa árvore de computação de cor ou escalar.
The generated code is similar to the shader code we wrote in the way that it calls <g3>Compute()<\/g3> and it returns the final result of our color or scalar compute tree.
After we generate the shader code, we set it to the respective key we need.
Depois de gerar o código do shader, definimo-lo para a respectiva chave que precisamos.
After we generate the shader code, we set it to the respective key we need.
In the effect file we check if this key is set, and if yes, we pass it to the stream defined in our shader code.
No arquivo de efeito verificamos se esta chave é definida, e se sim, passamos para o fluxo definido em nosso código de shader.
In the effect file we check if this key is set, and if yes, we pass it to the stream defined in our shader code.
